intro: Blepharis calcitrapa var. velutina, commonly known as the velvetleaf bluemouth, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, velvety foliage, which gives it its common name. The plant produces small, blue to violet flowers that bloom in the summer months. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and open habitats. Its structure and growth habits make it an interesting subject for botanical study, particularly in regions with limited water availability.
